docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Mandates and Mudslinging'' (column, Nov. 30): Paul Krugman dismisses Senator Barack Obama's points about health insurance mandates as ''echoing right-wing talking points'' on health care. Really?

headline.main: Health Insurance for All, Only if Everyone Pays?

docs.abstract: Two letters comment on Paul Krugman Nov 30 Op-Ed column in which he criticizes Democratic presidential hopeful Barack Obama's health care plan; John Walkmeyer and Peter Quince disagree with Krugman's assessment

docs.lead_paragraph: Henry from Mississippi, a conference call participant, put Fred D. Thompson on the spot today when he asked about illegal immigrants, saying they are needed to fill labor shortages in the construction, farming and poultry industries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democrats intend to focus on economic issues as Congress returns for a packed December agenda, while Republicans push for financing for the war in Iraq without conditions.

headline.main: Congress, Returning From Break, Has Much Work to Finish Before the Next One

byline.original: By CARL HULSE and DAVID STOUT

docs.lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa - At a news conference here just now, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton expanded her attacks on Senator Barack Obama by suggesting that he has a character issue because of his assertions that his health insurance plan covers all Americans (which she disputes) and because his old political action committee spread around money in early presidential nominating states.

headline.main: An Attack, From the Candidate's Mouth

docs.abstract: Clinton pledges to draw contrasts between herself and Obama
docs.snippet: Clinton pledges to draw contrasts between herself and Obama

docs.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES - Hillary Rodham Clinton's aides went to bed Saturday night with the bad news from the new Des Moines Register poll on their minds, and they woke up Sunday and quickly pounced on the poll's new No. 1, Barack Obama, with teeth bared.

headline.main: Battered by Poll, Clinton Hits Back

docs.abstract: Raising questions anew about Obama's use of PAC money
docs.snippet: Raising questions anew about Obama's use of PAC money

docs.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES - The big news in presidential politics this Sunday is the pole vault of Mike Huckabee into first place in the new Des Moines Register poll of likely Iowa Republican caucus-goers, who had appeared to favor the better-known, better-financed Mitt Romney for much of this year.

headline.main: Huckabee's Leap in Iowa Poll Reverberates

docs.abstract: A survey suggests Huckabee is the one to beat
docs.snippet: A survey suggests Huckabee is the one to beat
